discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Assigning the Teams Communications Support Engineer role is the correct choice because it provides access to activity reports without granting excessive permissions. This aligns with the principle of least privilege.

Selected Answer: C
C is correct. 
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/admin/activity-reports/activity-reports?view=o365-worldwide#who-can-see-reports

questions.question_text:
Your company uses Teams.

You are assigned the Teams Communications Support Specialist role.

You discover that you cannot read activity reports in the Microsoft 365 admin center.

You need to be assigned a role that will enable you to read the activity reports. The solution must follow the principle of least privilege.

Which role should be assigned to you?

Note: This question is part of a series of questions that present the same scenario. Each question in the series contains a unique solution that might meet the stated goals. Some question sets might have more than one correct solution, while others might not have a correct solution.
After you answer a question in this section, you will NOT be able to return to it. As a result, these questions will not appear in the review screen.
Your company has 10 offices in North America and Europe.
The company has 5,000 users.
You plan to deploy Microsoft Teams for all the users.
You run a pilot project for the planned deployment.
You need to identify the network packet loss from the pilot computers to Microsoft Teams during calls.
Solution: From the Microsoft Teams admin center, you run the Network Planner.
Does this meet the goal?

discussion.content:
I just found the following link, the network planner appears to be used to determine bandwidth needs, not packet loss.

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/tutorial-network-planner-example?tutorial-step=5

The network planner is used for deploying Teams:

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/prepare-network

comments.content:
yes it can. However, I believe it can only be installed/used on one computer at a time.

Teams call quality dashboard:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/quality-of-experience-review-guide

discussion.content: Network Companion Tool can help to analyze the network capability

Selected Answer: C
Audio quality and reliability for all clients and devices - Quality if Experience Report
Headset is a device so answer is correct

questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft 365 subscription that contains a user named User1.
User1 experiences audio issues while sharing his screen during Microsoft Teams meetings.
You need to investigate whether the headset of User1 causes the issues.
Which report should you use?

You have a Microsoft 365 subscription that uses Microsoft Teams and contains a user named User.
You need to ensure that User1 can investigate call-quality issues and identify the following types of information:

Caller and recipient names -
//IMG//

✑ Device names and IP addresses
✑ The number and names of all meeting participants
The solution must use the principle of least privilege.
Which role should you assign to User1?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
It is B

questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft 365 E5 subscription.
You need to generate a report that provides the following information:
✑ How many users post and reply to channel messages
✑ The number of ad hoc meetings organized by a user
✑ The number of meetings a user has participated in
✑ The total video time of a user
Which report should you run?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
The report name is 'Teams user activity', and the question is about the name of the report. So will go with A

Selected Answer: A
On exam 31/03/2023.
A is correct

Selected Answer: A
Only the Teams user activity report can fulfill the requirements.
Answer is A

Selected Answer: A
A is the correct because you have infor like Display Name / "post and reply to channel messages" in this report that you don't have the Teams usage.
"How many users post and reply to channel messages " should be under Teams usage rather than "Teams user activity".. so B for me
Seems to be B the link even points to "Teams Usage Reports" not "Teams user activity" as A represents.

comments.content: Teams User Activity is within Teams Usage Reports, I think it's just badly worded.

Hard to say maybe the link is bad, when you look for correct link "https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/teams-analytics-and-reports/user-activity-report"

For me it looks like Teams user activity fits better than Teams usage.
